text.p: The U.S. Defence Department on Wednesday night denied a report on Iraqi state television that U.S. missiles has been fired at military bases and civilian areas in the capital Baghdad, killing a number of people.

"There has been no attack," said Air Force Col. Doug Kennett, a Pentagon spokesman. He repeated earlier denials by President Bill Clinton and other Pentagon officials that any attack had been launched on Baghdad.
Iraq said U.S. missiles hit military bases and civilian areas in the capital on Wednesday evening, killing a number of people.

"At 8.45 p.m. the American enemy directed its failing missiles against our military bases and civilian places and a number of them have fallen in Baghdad," Iraqi state television reported, quoting a statement by the general command of the Iraqi armed forces.
Residents in Baghdad heard several large explosions, as well as anti-aircraft fire, but did not know what had caused them. Air-raid sirens sounded.

State television showed pictures of a building which it said was destroyed in the attack and a crater in a road in a residential area. Government officials said they would take reporters in Baghdad to see the damage.
